title: Have $300. Suggestions for a font family?
content:
Hi folks, new to the forum, but consider myself a neophyte type snob (that is, still a beginner, but I am a type nut nonetheless).  
I am a student, and purchased the Adobe Font Folio (academic), so I already own such faces as Helvetica, Avenir, Univers, Futura, etc etc,plus the faces that come with OS X and Adobe CS4.

What I lack is a really complete slab-serif family of fonts. I am thinking that purchasing a good slab-serif font would be a really useful addition to my library, so I am currently considering Jos’ Museo Slab family or H&FJ’s Archer. I see Archer everywhere, however, and I don’t want to invest in a library that could soon be ubiquitous/overused (if it isn’t already...)

Other faces I’m considering: Gotham, Verlag, some nice brush scripts like Alpine Script... maybe a combination of fonts. However, I can only afford spending up to $300 on fonts. I see the merit in getting one high-quality family (or at least a subset of a family) and learning how to use it really well.

I’d really appreciate your feedback!
author: bstrom

Hi, Brendan-

If you are looking for a slab serif family, you could take a look of my Suomi Slab Serif. It has six weights with italics. From MyFonts. This is shameless self-promotion, but there you go.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100103033414im_/http:/typophile.com/files/stf_SuomiSlab_poster_6706.png)
Actually came across your Suomi Slab family, Tomi. A source of inspiration! I will consider it, and I thank you for replying.
Just wanted to say that I’m very pleased you’re considering Museo Slab.

Your timing is very good: slab is the new black.  
(Hmmm, or are you simply following a trend? :-)

If you’re not in a huge rush, I would suggest waiting just  
a little bit: there will soon be a very nice one coming out.  
It’s warm, well-crafted, covers 50+ languages, and the  
italic is impressively progressive.

But really, first we need to narrow things down: what flavor of  
slab are you looking for? There are kiddie ones, industrial ones...

hhp

If you buy a slab serif for $160 or less and have $140 left over, and want a nice serif, consider Whitman by Kent Lew.

8 styles for for $140.

hhp

I think Hrant is on target in asking what kind of slab you are looking for, because they can be so different. For a happy sans you can’t do better than Museo, and a friendly one, Archer. [PMN Caecilia](http://web.archive.org/web/20100103033414/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/pmn-caecilia/) is a humanist slab, very nice for some clean looking text. The heavy condensed weights of [Dispatch](http://web.archive.org/web/20100103033414/http:/fontbureau.com/fonts/Dispatch) look great in headlines, for which they were designed. [Soho](http://web.archive.org/web/20100103033414/http:/www.seblester.co.uk/type_lettering.php?CategoryId=7)’s heavy weights are pretty, and somehow say ’magazine’ more to me. Newsy, but very stylish is [Stag](http://web.archive.org/web/20100103033414/http:/christianschwartz.com/stagsans.shtml), which is my favorite at the moment.

I add PMN Caecilia, a wonderful and handy slab.  
 [http://www.linotype.com/de/1313/pmncaecilia-schriftfamilie.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20100103033414/http:/www.linotype.com/de/1313/pmncaecilia-schriftfamilie.html "http://www.linotype.com/de/1313/pmncaecilia-schriftfamilie.html")

I have looked through all the suggestions and I will try to answer some of your questions. I confess, I do not quite understand all the nuances between styles of slab-serif. In terms of pure subjective taste, I prefer slabs that are more geometric, with very little contrast between thick/thin strokes, which Museo and Archer seem to fit quite well. I stumbled across House Industries’ Neutraface Slab last night, and am really considering that or Neutraface No 2.

I like The Serif from LucasFonts, but it feels awfully similar to Chaparral to me, which I own, and I’m looking for building up as much diversity in my font library as possible. On my sticky note of serious considerations, I now have the following: Archer, Museo Slab, Neutraface Slab, Neutraface 2, and Gotham.

I’m delighted to see you frequent these forums, Jos! I feel like I’ve stumbled upon a goldmine of knowledge and expertise. I myself am designing a geometric slab-serif... which may not turn out to be any good, but I am learning a ton in the process. Part of the reason I want to purchase a geometric slab is for study purposes.

Be careful, it might be difficult to outgrow  
something you admire once you dissect it.

hhp

<cite>I myself am designing a geometric slab-serif... which may not turn out to be any good, but I am learning a ton in the process. Part of the reason I want to purchase a geometric slab is for study purposes.</cite>

Type design can only be mastered by exercising it a lot together with looking a lot at your own and other designs. Because Museo Slab 500 and 500 italic are already free you might want to opt for Archer or something else. That way you have more material to reference to :)

Jos, you are standup. I really enjoyed reading your recent interview w/ MyFonts.

Does anyone have any opinions regarding NeutraFace or Gotham? Like I said, my choices aren’t necessarily limited to slab-serif... I’m just looking to pump as much diversity into my library as possible.

It is obviously advantageous to have a diverse library in itself, but making choices will be easier if you have a better idea of what typefaces you will need for your projects. So you may consider setting aside a typeface budget, so that when a project comes along for which you need something other than what you have in your current library, you can choose to buy one tailored for that project. You can build up your library organically that way.

Tomi, it is widely considered bad form to post several times in quick succession in a thread. So try to contain your thoughts to one post at a time. You may add a second post only if you have a substantial addition to make. But if you just want to add one more sentence right after you’ve posted something, use the edit button and add it to your last post; if you do it quickly enough, your post won’t even be marked as edited.

I know this is not perhaps an immediately obvious rule, but not to follow it may turn people against you unnecessarily.

Sorry, Brian-

I will keep my posts in singular form from now on.

Sentinel by H&FJ is arguably one of the most beautifully rendered and refined slabs to come about. Brendan, I am right now reading the monumental “Adrian Frutiger Typefaces. The Complete Works”. In the discussion of his slab serif, Serifa, there is a wonderful classification of slab serifs on p. 168. It’s a classification by structure and really gives a lot of insight into the form. If you are going to work on a slab serif I would definitely recommend having a look at it in a library. Interestingly, Frutiger regards Serifa as “one of my worst attempts at a typeface.”

<cite>Interestingly, Frutiger regards Serifa as “one of my worst attempts at a typeface.”</cite>

I would agree with him!

James, I agree that it’s pretty much of a disaster, but it’s interesting that the designer himself feels the same way. One of the beauties of the book is the absolute frankness of Frutiger about his own work. And at his best, like Frutiger, the typeface, he’s tops.

I had the “pleasure” of drawing several variations of Serifa for a major magazine a few years ago. I could not understand what the art director saw in the design. Ah, the satisfaction of the custom type design!

\> Frutiger regards Serifa as “one of my worst attempts at a typeface.”

It’s nice to see such open self-criticism.  
But nothing can beat that Devanagari mutant.

hhp

James, as you worked on it you might be interested in more of the quote.

“Serifa is one of my worst attempts at a typeface, I think it’s fair to say. Not because of the characters that were unusual for me [he notes these earlier], but because my idea of a constructivist slab serif face was wrong for the eye. I always wanted to make readable faces. And Serifa just isn’t comfortable to read, it doesn’t flow well enough because of its wide fit. One could use it for posters. Serifa is pretty meaningless and yet it endures. That’s the tragic thing about typefaces, they stick around and always will. Once you design one you have to be able to stand by it.”

\> Serifa is pretty meaningless and yet it endures.

Like I said elsewhere recently:  
Popularity has a very weak correspondence with quality.

hhp
